events.target_title: evince 3.32.0: cannot locate ITS rules for evince-pdfdocument.metainfo.xml.in

note.body:
This isn't a MacOS problem - I'm seeing it on GNU/Linux too.

The problem is that msgfmt needs a .loc file so that it knows how to extract translatable strings from .metainfo.xml files. metainfo.loc and metainfo.its are provided by AppStream, so you can fix this by installing AppStream (or just those two files from it).

Screen is skewed/distorted in Wayland sessions using Matrox G200eW3

note.body:
I have a very similar problem on Fedora 29, which is currently mutter 3.30.2 (with a few small patches in the SRPM).

In my case, I have two identical monitors.  The desktop (gnome-shell) is fine on one display.  However, on the second monitor, any windows and desktop background are skewed as in the screenshot attached by the original issue reporter.  The mouse pointer is not distorted.  The Fedora logo also displays correctly prior to gnome-shell starting.

From git history, 3.30.2 contains !225, suggested as a possibly fix. So, assuming my problem is the same, then the patch in !225 does not fix the problem.

I built a new RPM of 3.32.0, but discovered ca7c5c12 bumped the API to 4, `libmutter.so.4`.  As the `gnome-shell` and `gnome-tweak` RPMS are compiled against `libmutter.so.3`, it seems the furthest I could go (without rebuilding those other RPMS) is 3.31.2.

While investigating, I also noticed #3.

In any case, I will probably try to find a desktop environment which does not depend on mutter for now and test again with Fedora 30 in a few months and report back.

Update: An XFCE environment exhibits the same problem.  I believe XFCE does not depend on mutter, so I will continue debugging.

events.target_title: [Xorg + NVIDIA] [Wayland + NVIDIA] 144hz monitor locks to 60hz in dual monitor setup

note.body:
Wow! You're absolutely right! I got 144fps working in Xorg+NVIDIA! For anyone with the same problem in the future: The reason, as it turns out, is that the "Sync to this display" option in the NVIDIA settings application seems to be completely ignored. I got it working by appending the following to my `/etc/environment` file:
> __GL_SYNC_DISPLAY_DEVICE=DP-2

where `DP-2` is my 144hz monitor.
However, this seems to *NOT* take effect until the NVIDIA settings application is actually launched. If someone knows a better way to do it, please let me know, but until then, I'll put it in my startup applications.

Am I lacking some dependencies?

events.target_title: How to maintain API stability

note.body:
With 3.32, even extensions, which constitute Gnome Classic, are broken: for example, Window List.
Among other important and widely used extensions, broken are Dash to Dock, Em Dash, Volume Mixer.
In particular, the simultaneous failure of Window List, Dash to Dock, Em Dash, (and an excellent TaskBar, completely broken in 3.30) makes the Gnome desktop hardly usable for people who want to have an overview of which apps are currently running, at glance, without any key press.

events.target_title: How to maintain API stability

note.body:
Thanks! Yes, it seems that everything was not too bad. Just that many of the other extensions weren't updated at extensions.gnome.org but had working versions available from source.

Get well soon!:)

events.target_title: TopIcon Plus makes GS consume 40-50% cpu time

note.body:
Same problem here - no matter which extension I use (TopIcons, TopIcons Plus, TopIcons Redux) CPU usage goes up to 60 - 80%. But in the meantime I've installed "Dash to Panel" extension which replaces my system top panel. With this extension enabled CPU usage goes back to normal values. When I disable dash-to-panel CPU usage goes up again. In my case I want to use Dash To Panel so I'm covered for now but I thought it might be good to mention that.

Cheers, Wojtek

events.target_title: Very large images crash the system
app: allow to close a GimpToolPolygon without committing it

note.body:
Can this please be turned into an option, hidden away in preferences? I don't mind it to be the standard, but it confused me a good day or so, and I really like the old way of closing the polygon and directly be able to cut my selection.

And I'm not alone, just google it..

Thank you in advance!

Import photographed documents (rotate/crop/color corrections/metadata)
Import photographed documents (rotate/crop/color corrections/metadata)

note.body:
Thanks for your input guys!

>  @mjourdan : If I understand correctly, what @HaMF suggests is to use a camera as a new input source, so that it would be possible to directly take snaps from Paperwork.

I'm actually proposing to import photo-files. As I read in an other issue (#179 probably), porting to android is challenging and won't happen any time soon. Until then, I am not too enthusiastic about the feature. Holding the receipt in front of the laptop's webcam just doesn't cut it for me ;)

nb: At least for my laptop, the webcam already works as an input to the scanning interface. Let me know if you need details.

>  @jflesch : The way things are done currently, Paperwork does not keep an historic of image [...] rotation, cropping, automatic color equalization. I think what you suggest could easily fit in here.

This is a very good point. I agree that you auto-rotate/-crop/-skew correction would fit in there just as well. Is there a way to access these functions from the cli? If not, it does not fit my use case: I want to reduce the amounts of clicks needed to get a useful recorded document from a picture. Ideally: one click on the cameras release button. 

I disagree, that modifying the picture on import is an issue: Before the user even has any chance to delete the original file he sees the result of the processing finalized. If he then decides to delete the original file it's a choice ("the quality is good enough") that we should just respect. For scanned images on the other hand, I agree that it would be an issue since the intermediate result of the scan is not stored anywhere obvious.

> @jflesch : In the coming months, I will work on [reorganizing/rewriting Paperwork to make it much more modular [...]

I have seen the issue and I this would help tremendously. I suspected, however, that it will take quite some time until it lands. Do you have an estimate when you will get around to doing it? In any case, I don't think working on automatic transforms etc. now is still worth it. I think the main task is to get the algorithm fleshed out and robust. We can copy this to whatever plugin framework fairly easily I'd suppose.

> @jflesch : Beware that OpenCV is potentially a dependency/packaging nightmare.

Thanks for the warning. I've heard of that but luckily have not experienced it myself yet. OpenCV would probably be the quickest solution to start with. I think basic auto-rotation and skew correction can be implemented in vanilla python still. But I have yet to dive into that try it on real world images.

(Edit:Love the "I have a dream" tag :nerd:)

events.target_title: Half-star precision ratings
Half-star precision ratings

note.body:
FR: feature request

other players: I'm mainly used to Clementine / AmaroK, I assume any other player that uses [TagLib](https://taglib.org/) would behave the same way.

I found the FMPS specifications on [https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Specifications/free-media-player-specs/](https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Specifications/free-media-player-specs/), specifically sections 2.2.1 "All Rating Tags" and 2.2.2 "FMPS_Rating", which defines a rating that's a float between 0 and 1 and that corresponds to what I see on my files (eg: 3.5 stars on Clementine shows up as a 0.7 "Fmps Rating")

events.target_title: Half-star precision ratings

note.body: They can but the precision is then lost so it wouldn't interoperate well with software that has 10 levels of precision. (Importing the ratings into rhythmbox db then exporting them back to the files would be lossy.)

events.target_title: Half-star precision ratings

note.body:
I think half-star precision is plenty, a star system doesn't go farther (the UI would be atrocious). I just did a short survey:

* float: vlc, DeaDBeeF
* half-star (out of 5): Clementine, Amarok, Quod Libet, Mediamonkey (windows)
* star (out of 5): Rhythmbox, Banshee, Guayadeque
* no rating whatsoever: Audacious
* other: iTunes defaults to 1-star precision but half-star can be activated as a setting. gmusicbrowser main interface shows rounded 1-star precision but the songs properties have the corresponding editable 0-100 scores.

An issue with Rhythmbox one-star precision is that it doesn't use the files' tags directly, so importing tags then exporting them using an external script means losing all that precision (or all the changes made on Rhythmbox), whereas I can import my library in Guayadesque and it only shows me one-star rounded ratings but it only overwrites the files' ratings when it's explicitly told to do so.

Keyboard shortcut for Join / Mirror / Single display options under Keyboard settings

note.body:
HI, thanks for the quick answer...

Firstly, now I am ashamed at myself for not even trying to press the combination. In my defence I did google for this first without finding an answer and I did look in the Gnome keyboard settings and this shortcut is not described/listed there.

Secondly, I went to try it now and yes - as you said there are some issues with it. My issue in particular is that I was able to Join the displays, but it seems that going back to 1 display setup is beyond it :dagger: 

Pressing Super + P gives me the following options:
1.  Mirror - works, makes both monitors on the lowest denomination resolution, useless option for me, but I understand why it's there
2.  Join - works more or less properly (it adjusted my TV to a 720p resolution because that is what the TV itself is broadcasting, instead of 1080p of which it is capable and which I have set up already in the Display settings)
3. External display - does nothing for me, displays remain joined - perhaps because both displays are external in my case, don't have a built in one - I have my main display connected to a DP port, and a TV connected to HDMI
4. Built in display - does nothing for me since I don't have a built in monitor

As you noted, it seems this option is using it's own settings instead of reflecting the options that are already set-up in the Display settings section. It would be nice if it was able to do that instead - offer me External display 1 and External display 2 (Primary / Secondary) to choose from. Also what would happen in a case I had 3 monitors attached? I'm pretty sure that Display settings would pick them all up correctly, but this shortcut would have issues with it. If the shortcut was using the already set-up Display settings the issues would probably be avoided.

Best regards,
Dalibor

events.target_title: "Join all monitors" option in the display switcher results in a blank desktop. This display switcher needs to be LESS accessible.

note.body:
Hi there, in my search for the keyboard shortcut for display switching I was pointed to this thread...

I use a PC (Antergos, up-to-date, Gnome 3.32), not a laptop and have a main 4K display attached via DP port and a 1080p TV attached via HDMI. I am able to switch between Join and Single displays just fine by using Gnome display settings, but invoking Super + P option is not really working as advertised. I get the following options offered:

1. Mirror - does it's thing, adjusts both monitors to lowest denomination resolution
2. Join - it does join the displays, but my TV gets adjusted to 720p resolution and not to 1080p that was already set up in the Display settings in gnome-control-center
3. External 1 - does the wrong thing - Joins the displays, instead of going to only one display
4. Built-in - does nothing for me because I dont have a built in display

Why is this shortcut doing it's own thing instead of simply referring to the settings that are already set up under Display settings in GNOME settings? It should offer only what is available there and we should also be able to disable options that we are not interested in (Mirror in my case) to dispense with unecessary clicks... Don't get me wrong - I am not saying remove the Mirror option altogether, just to be able to disable it from showing as an option when pressing Super + P. It should remain there in Display settings where it's currently sitting, there is nothing wrong with that.

My suggestion for ergonomics of this shortcut would be: 
1.  Set up everything first in Display settings
2.  Under each option in display settings (Join / Mirror / Single) put a checkmark to enable/disable from showing when Super + P is pressed
3. Instead of showing External and Built in display options (not everyone uses laptops), it should show options that are available under Single, namely Primary and Secondary display. This would cover both notebook users ('primary' would I guess default to built-in display) and PC users alike.

In this case, the shortcut would cycle only through the already set-up options under Display settings and there would probably be no weird issues with it, provided that the person has set up the Display settings to his/her liking beforehand. I have had 0 issues so far with Display settings since I set them up and it would be really nice not to have to go under Settings -> Display every time I want to switch or join displays.

I even created mockups of the suggestion, see attached...

![Join_option_-_mockup](/uploads/a6332a910603e416f667cbc221e0efae/Join_option_-_mockup.png)
![Mirror_option_-_mockup](/uploads/97656051d2e8488a39a0b9c5069b6619/Mirror_option_-_mockup.png)
![Single_option_-_mockup](/uploads/2f88f555a9bb4f22911168dfd6a1e888/Single_option_-_mockup.png)

note.body:
I believe that gvfs should let ssh do its thing. Any other solution will create problems.

>  It was not possible to use the standard port with gvfs if a custom port was specified in `ssh_config`, which is a bigger problem.

I would argue that this solution creates more problems. A user that used a non standard port would probably also create a ~/.ssh/config file. Or at least they would after googling it. The current solution is: You have custom ports? Always use the full urls.

> If we change that, it would be possible to change the port in this file and achieve the wanted behavior. 

I do not agree. The file location is under /usr/share - not etc, it will be overridden by upgrades, it adds more configuration files, more documentation and (the most important) it will only work for 1 port.

note.body: Indeed, I had a feeling there was a similar bug but I had trouble finding it.

events.target_title: Ability to change Date format

note.body:
First, Americans such as myself are much more familiar with the %M-%D-%YY format than %D-%M-%YY format. Allowing Nautilus to utilize their preferred date format will ease confusion among Americans.

Second, I often work with folders that have date stamps that span several years, and I need to sort files by date stamp in those folders and view the dates alongside the filenames and filesizes. Being able to view the date stamps in full ISO 8601 format can make it MUCH, MUCH faster for my eyes and brain to process (since Roman letters and numbers are read left-right, and not right-left).

Additionally there are circumstances in Nautilus where it certain aspects of the date field outright do not show. For example, folders and files that are old enough omit the timestamp (unless the "Modified -- Time" column is active), and files that are young enough omit the year stamp outright. There is no way to override this feature. Allowing the ability to modify the date format can remove this issue.

events.target_title: Ability to change Date format

No it would not, because it is not ISO 8601.

events.target_title: Ability to change Date format

note.body:
All the same, Nautilus still doesn't provide a way to easily change the date and time format, and its not respecting my locale configs.

First, here is the output of locale and date +%c on my system:
![Screenshot_20190524_202628__1_](/uploads/e8d8980f2880ddf69e01722c4454e1a3/Screenshot_20190524_202628__1_.png)

Nautilus ignores this outright, and does its own thing:

![Screenshot_20190524_202935](/uploads/54b59eca3856dfb7575ac1a5b7881f8f/Screenshot_20190524_202935.png)

But if we compare to other file managers...

KDE Dolphin defaults to my locale settings, and requires changing my locale settings to change the format.

![Screenshot_20190524_202628](/uploads/6b020e509ba04568a55225333357c64c/Screenshot_20190524_202628.png)

Thunar, the default file manager for XFCE, defaults to a certain setting but easily allows changing the date format in its options.

![Screenshot_20190524_202739](/uploads/19862c938141a9e1fb91844924aacc80/Screenshot_20190524_202739.png)

Caja, the default file manager for the MATE desktop (and a fork of Nautilus), also allows changing the date format, albeit with less options than Thunar.

![Screenshot_20190524_202847](/uploads/ef2c978d104930e1455db6a9d27b13a3/Screenshot_20190524_202847.png)

All I want is a setting under Preferences that I can modify to set my date/time format to whatever format I want, the same that Thunar and Caja offer by default.

events.target_title: Ability to change Date format

note.body:
So instead of adding a relatively simple feature to nautilus, which
would be relatively simple to maintain, your suggestion is to add
complexity to the entire system by making end users:

1. Download and install another package from their repos
2. Download untrusted code off the internet
3. Know *where* to install said untrusted code
4. Execute said untrusted code.

Installing another package is a non-starter in many workplace
environments. And I'm not going to get into the issues with plugins and
downloading/executing untrusted code. There's been enough of that in the
news lately. [1]

1: https://thehackernews.com/2019/07/linux-gnome-spyware.html

note.body:
> There are lot of people using nautilus. Every single one can have their own preferred date&time format so Nautilus will gain nothing by adding 2 different or 10 different formats in preferences until you add all possible formats, or there is possibility to define your own string for formatting date.

Which is something other file browsers already let you do as a primary feature.

At the least, Nautilus should be respecting my locale settings. As you see in previous comments on this thread, it doesn't even do that.

> And going further this way – why not add way for user to add more columns with info? Why not make it possible to show length of video or size of photo?

I'm all for that, and I'm sure other users are too. It's something other file browsers also do as primary features. But that is a topic for another thread.

events.target_title: Shell crashes when I try to enable Extensions via GNOME Tweaks and access Activities overview

note.body:
So after doing a bit more digging I've worked out what specifically I can do to prevent my shell from crashing. I had the extension [Multi Monitors Add On](https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/921/multi-monitors-add-on/) installed but it was in an error state and therefore couldn't be disabled. Uninstalling that extension has stopped the crashes from occurring.

I've contributed to a bug report in the extension itself, however I believe it is still a bug that gnome-shell crashes due to an extension.

events.target_title: Resizing partition changes PARTUUID and makes system unbootable

note.body: I think I've also ran into this issue on a rpi. This is caused by what I think is a bug in parted, see https://debbugs.gnu.org/35714. It is triggered on the rpi since that has an MBR partition table without any bootup code (which the rpi does not need). See the linked report for details, and see https://github.com/RPi-Distro/pi-gen/pull/285 for a change to the rpi image generation to prevent this bug from being triggered.

events.target_title: Support to unlock screen with U2F device only

note.body:
I was actually just working on a similar usecase: Use a complex password to log in, and a simple password to unlock. This mostly serves to have a complex password to unlock my keyrings and encrypted filesystems, while still having a quick password for unlocking.

I can handle the different passwords using something like `libpam-pwdfile`, but I can't seem to distinguish between lock and login from PAM.

In terms of implementation, I can imagine that gdm uses a different PAM service for unlocking vs login, or perhaps it can expose an environment variable that some pam module can check for (though a quick scan through the default modules shows none that would qualify).

events.target_title: Support to unlock screen with U2F device only

note.body:
> I know very little about PAM but my impression was that every service used a different file in /etc/pam.d.

Correct.

> So my preferred solution would be to use "gdm-password" for initial login and "gpm-unlock" for the other case. That way, I could add "auth sufficient pam_u2f.so cue" to the latter file.

Yeah, that's what I meant with "I can imagine that gdm uses a different PAM service for unlocking vs login".


Note that I cobbled up a workaround for this using the `pam_script` module, see https://unix.stackexchange.com/a/538032/233460

note.body:
Actually I think having the check is the proper way to do it, even if `texture_2d_is_get_data_supported` is implemented or not. Having the check doesn't removes any features, it makes the code more robust.
So best would be to leave the check AND implement `texture_2d_is_get_data_supported` :)

events.target_title: GLib.assert_false does not work correctly
GLib.assert_false does not work correctly

note.body:
With `[Assert]` annotation Valac generates this C code for above vala code:  
```
...
#define _vala_assert(expr, msg) if G_LIKELY (expr) ; else g_assertion_message_expr (G_LOG_DOMAIN, __FILE__, __LINE__, G_STRFUNC, msg);
...
_vala_main (gchar** args, int args_length1)
{
  _vala_assert (TRUE, "true");
  _vala_assert (TRUE, "true");
  _vala_assert (TRUE, "true");   // arg must be inverse
  _vala_assert (FALSE, "false"); // arg must be inverse
}
```
This code wrong and gives error message:  
```
ERROR: ... /assert_false.vala.c:32:_vala_main: assertion failed: (false)
```
This is not very informative.

With comment out `[Assert]` in glib-2.0.vapi it gives this:  
```
void
_vala_main (gchar** args, int args_length1)
{
  g_assert (TRUE);
  g_assert_true (TRUE);
  g_assert_false (TRUE);  // abort 
  g_assert_false (FALSE);
}
```
This code gives:  
```
ERROR: ... /assert_false.vala.c:26:_vala_main: 'TRUE' should be FALSE
```
This more informative and code work correctly.  

Why this `_vala_assert` macro? And package glib-2.0 is default for Valac, why it's interfaces don't work all correct?

Meld doesn't store preferences (due to "gsettings-backend-dconf" not being installed)

note.body:
It means exactly that, any settings changed from the "Preferences" window are not persisted after restating the application.
They DO get applied as long as the Meld instance is not closed, but once you run Meld again, the preferences are reset to the defaults.
I tested changing settings from "Editor", "Folder Comparisons", "Version Control", "File Filters" and "Text Filters" tabs.

I'll edit the description.

events.target_title: Meld doesn't store preferences (due to "gsettings-backend-dconf" not being installed)

note.body:
I managed to fix it. The thing is that a package called "gsettings-backend-dconf" is not a hard dependency for meld in my distro. It appears only as recommended package and it wasn't installed. 

After installing gsettings-backend-dconf, dconf and libdconf were installed as dependencies.

I will report this to openSUSE, it seems that dconf should be a dependency for meld.

Thanks for your attention and I apologize for the inconvenient.

another thing, that would be nice, would be to better find files in the include section in order to actually be able to use the hints when underscored in red. I assume the paths interpreted by the compiler also include formats that builder isn't yet capable of recognising.

But it is really strange how setting the logfile changes the behaviour dramatically. :/

note.body:
> I'm not happy with this approach, though.

Yes, particularly if the issue with flashing would still be there (I noticed it too, somewhat random but very troublesome).

The maintainer of wl-clipboard is thinking about implementing a less hacky manager demon which would be, I think, event-driven rather than polling, so the issue *should* not arise anymore in that case. In fact, this script of mine was itself meant as a workaround for having a clipboard manager while waiting for that.

events.target_title: Doesn't allow selecting text when an other paste event is taking place
Doesn't allow selecting text when an other paste event is taking place

note.body:
@bugaevc Did some more trials. What I'm experiencing is not properly the flickering mentioned by @egmontkob , but a strange duplication of gnome-terminal's window when I do right-click to open the menu and move the cursor to select an item (ONLY if [my clipboard demon](https://gist.github.com/yory8/d0ea72048ecd499a0af8032aa56fc8bb) is running). It's hard to explain, a blank window flickers up, then if I switch windows around the windows it disappears. It happens always, so you should be able to replicate it.

1. launch the demon
2. open a new gnome-terminal window
3. in this window, right-click and move the cursor to select something, like "Preferences". It will flicker, than a black window will take focus. If you $mod-arrow to change focused window, it will disappear.

This is NOT a vte clipboard. Just tried on firefox, it breaks opening all menus (right-click, bookmarks, history, etc). It's wl-clipboard, and it actually seems like something that would happen because of loss of focus. Opening an issue on @bugaevc repo.

I'm using wl-clipboard 1.0.0

events.target_title: Doesn't allow selecting text when an other paste event is taking place

note.body:
Issue solved! apparently, the wl-clipboard in arch repos is not actually the 1.0 version, even though it's advertised as such. I installed wl-clipboard from latest master and it works perfectly (on sway). Not only no more broken menus, but also perfect selection.

This can be considered closed. :fireworks:

events.target_title: JPEG files saved in GIMP 2.10 make Windows 10's File Explorer show a "The size is unexpected" error

note.body:
I have the same problem. I couldn't add tags to photo files in File Explorer. Then I realised the problem only occurred with photo's I had edited with GIMP. I'm also working with WIN 10 and GIMP 2.10.8.

So, problem is not fixed yet?
Best solution for me now is to use previous version of GIMP?

events.target_title: JPEG files saved in GIMP 2.10 make Windows 10's File Explorer show a "The size is unexpected" error

note.body:
![0403.19_5_27g](/uploads/6bad12656cc49d020b86df5a60c62612/0403.19_5_27g.JPG)

![0403.19_5_27g__test_](/uploads/fb19ba1a53ccac4fa319009567eab265/0403.19_5_27g__test_.JPG)

Error code is 0x88982F8F. I tried to reproduce it with several images from other sources, but the error didn't occur. I can reproduce the error with photo's from the same source, the same folder in File Explorer.

For instance with image '0403.19_5_27g.JPG' I can add tags without getting an error. Then I open the image in GIMP and save it to a new file with File > 'Export as'. In the new file '0403.19_5_27g__test_.JPG' I get the error when I try to add an tag or adjust other properties. The error happens also when I don't make a single adjustment to the image, just with opening en saving.
The strange thing is that I don't get the error when I remove an already excisting tag from that file.

events.target_title: JPEG files saved in GIMP 2.10 make Windows 10's File Explorer show a "The size is unexpected" error

note.body:
I have no IT background, so I'll try my best to explain the issue, but I can't get too technical.

>  In particular you all talk about "tags". What is a tag? Is it metadata? (XMP, EXIF? IPTC?)

In Windows you can add tags/labels/keywords to files to help with organizing and searching files in File Explorer. See for example: [](https://www.howtogeek.com/344543/how-to-tag-any-windows-file-for-easy-organization/)

The tags are visible in File Explorer on the same location as where EXIF data is shown: File properties > details. See first picture in the link above. This is also the location where you can give a rating or adjust other properties. It must be metadata then?

>  Well I can find it is [WINCODEC_ERR_UNEXPECTEDSIZE](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/wic/-wic-codec-error-codes) error code, which indeed corresponds to the text message. But I can't find a thing about **what** it actually means. What is unexpected in the size? The size of what? Of the file? Of some metadata?

Yeah, I had the same outcome. It's hard to find what the error exactly is and what a solution is. This means probably that the error is pretty rare?

events.target_title: Airplane Mode key disables only input (a bluetooth keyboard)

note.body:
I've discovered explaining over the phone how to get this system back into a useable state after pressing this "key-of-death" is no fun at all...

I'm currently looking into workaround, specially just disabling that key.  No luck so far, but documenting here in case someone wants to take this up.

1.  It doesn't seem to be listed in Gnome Preferences -> Keyboard.
      - I can't find it using `dconf-editor`
      - Relevant symbols seem to be `XF86WLAN` or maybe `XF86RFKill`/`XF86Bluetooth`.
      - https://www.reddit.com/r/archlinux/comments/9m00vb/disable_wifi_key_on_thinkpad/

2.  `Xmodmap` doesn't work with Wayland (?)  Maybe I could switch my system back to Xorg but I haven't tried.
      - https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/292868/how-to-customise-keyboard-mappings-with-wayland
      - So hacking `/usr/share/X11/xkb/keycodes/evdev` might work, although unpleasant to change files under /usr.

3.  At the kernel level, some blacklisting of `rfkill` or `wmi_<sth>` might work, seems heavy-handed.

4.  Making the system run `rkkill unblock all` on boot might help: at least then a hard reboot would enable bluetooth again.

events.target_title: Airplane Mode key disables only input (a bluetooth keyboard)

note.body:
Update: modifying evdev as follows disables the "key-of-death":
```dif
--- xkb_evedev.orig	2019-07-21 09:48:21.841768578 -0700
+++ /usr/share/X11/xkb/keycodes/evdev	2019-07-21 11:11:14.314598110 -0700
@@ -271,19 +271,19 @@
 	<I241> = 241;	// #define KEY_FORWARDMAIL         233
 	<I242> = 242;	// #define KEY_SAVE                234
 	<I243> = 243;	// #define KEY_DOCUMENTS           235
 	<I244> = 244;	// #define KEY_BATTERY             236
-	<I245> = 245;	// #define KEY_BLUETOOTH           237
-	<I246> = 246;	// #define KEY_WLAN                238
+	<I245> = 372;	// #define KEY_BLUETOOTH           237
+	<I246> = 372;	// #define KEY_WLAN                238
 	<I247> = 247;	// #define KEY_UWB                 239
 	<I248> = 248;	// #define KEY_UNKNOWN             240
 	<I249> = 249;	// #define KEY_VIDEO_NEXT          241
 	<I250> = 250;	// #define KEY_VIDEO_PREV          242
 	<I251> = 251;	// #define KEY_BRIGHTNESS_CYCLE    243
 	<I252> = 252;	// #define KEY_BRIGHTNESS_ZERO     244
 	<I253> = 253;	// #define KEY_DISPLAY_OFF         245
-	<I254> = 254;	// #define KEY_WWAN                246
-	<I255> = 255;	// #define KEY_RFKILL              247
+	<I254> = 372;	// #define KEY_WWAN                246
+	<I255> = 372;	// #define KEY_RFKILL              247
 
 	<I372> = 372;   // #define KEY_FAVORITES           364
 	<I382> = 382;   // #define KEY_KEYBOARD            374
 	<I569> = 569;   // #define KEY_ROTATE_LOCK_TOGGLE  561
```
I tried doing this in `/usr/local/share/...` but that didn't seem to work: had to modify the `/usr/share/...` directly :(

note.body:
I'm surprised this was opened 5 years ago and not fixed.

I can confirm that this is a problem. I think it is something to do with the default unit. I use A4, and in my region metric units are standard.

If I print from Libreoffice everything seems to be fine.

If I print from a PDF produced by Libreoffice in Evince, the margins are wrong.

If I print the PDF to a PS file in Evince, and then send the PS file to my printer things seem to be correct.

I observed that most things are under Milimeters except for the margin sizes. Ie if I go Print > Page Setup > Manage Custom Sizes.

My printer in cups defintely has the right units:

events.target_title: Cannot move the map or zoom using the mouse on wayland

note.body:
I suffer from the same issue, also running an AMD GPU (see bottom). Note this bug has been reported before in [Debian](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=909241). Also note that the mouse scroll wheel doesn't work. Both click and scroll mouse events in the mapview are not working for me.

After some testing I found that under wayland the `button-press-event` event of MapView._mapView does not fire (mainWindow.js:L257). This event does fire under with the x11 GDK_BACKEND. I've tried setting the BUTTON_PRES_MASK event mask as per the [GTK docs](https://lazka.github.io/pgi-docs/Gtk-3.0/classes/Widget.html#Gtk.Widget.signals.button_press_event), to no avail unfortunately. Any pointers on how I could try and diagnose the issue any further? 

Update: I've captured the output of one 'click LMB and hold, drag and release LMB' sequence with WAYLAND_DEBUG=1. Output is attached in [wayland_debug_output.txt](/uploads/9baf00aa4f25ba0614bd17bea9ef42c7/wayland_debug_output.txt). Maybe someone with a working setup (e.g. intel card) could compare the output?

My GPU:
```
$ lspci -vnn | grep VGA -A 10

03:00.0 VGA compatible controller [0300]: Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. [AMD/ATI] Vega 10 XL/XT [Radeon RX Vega 56/64] [1002:687f] (rev c3) (prog-if 00 [VGA controller])
	Subsystem: Sapphire Technology Limited Vega 10 XL/XT [Radeon RX Vega 56/64] [1da2:e376]
	Flags: bus master, fast devsel, latency 0, IRQ 33
	Memory at d0000000 (64-bit, prefetchable) [size=256M]
	Memory at e0000000 (64-bit, prefetchable) [size=2M]
	I/O ports at e000 [size=256]
	Memory at efc00000 (32-bit, non-prefetchable) [size=512K]
	Expansion ROM at 000c0000 [disabled] [size=128K]
	Capabilities: <access denied>
	Kernel driver in use: amdgpu
	Kernel modules: amdgpu
```

events.target_title: Cannot move the map or zoom using the mouse on wayland

note.body:
After some digging, I found the culprit in an upstream package: clutter. For my setup (i.e. wayland, AMD gfx) clutter fails to pick the correct actor which should process the button-press-event. A quick and dirt work-around involves a gnome-maps-specific libclutter-1.0.so library where the pick result is hard coded to the id of the ChamplainViewport actor in gnome-maps (3). 

I'm unsure how much effort is involved in fixing picking in clutter under wayland on amd systems. Additionally, I get the impression that the [clutter dependency of libchamplain](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/clutter) has been abandoned and that all development of clutter has moved to [mutter-4 clutter](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/tree/master/clutter) for a while now (libmutter-clutter). Potentially the picking bug has been fixed there already (the code looks significantly refactored). In the long term libchamplain might want to migrate to the new fork (?) of libclutter. 

Could someone more experienced suggest the best course of action for getting this fixed though? Is libclutter still under active development?

events.target_title: Cannot move the map or zoom using the mouse on wayland

note.body:
Given your clarification, investing any considerable effort in fixing the bug upstream appears to be ill-advised. 

For those on Wayland/AMD that need a work-around, you can consider patching libclutter to include a hardcoded actor id as a picking result. Note that this patch might break other applications that run on libmutter, so make sure to save the patched lib file outside of the paths where your system searches for shared libraries. On my system this is /usr/local/lib, set --prefix below to a location suitable for your system. 
```
git clone https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/clutter.git
cd clutter
```
get clutter-stage.c.patch from attachment: [clutter-stage.c.patch](/uploads/36456154f3aa7bd7373eb87208d9a8d1/clutter-stage.c.patch) 
```
patch -p0 < clutter-stage.c.patch
./autogen.sh
./configure --prefix=/usr/local
make
make install
```
You should find the patched lib file under `<prefix>/lib/libclutter-1.0.so`

One way to force gnome-maps to load the patched lib is as follows:
`LD_LIBRARY_PATH=<prefix>/lib gnome-maps`
Click and scroll mouse events should now be passed on to the mapview.

events.target_title: Cannot move the map or zoom using the mouse on wayland

note.body:
The issue appears to be related to rgb10 support, disabling this works around the issue for me: 
`allow_rgb10_configs=false gnome-maps`

Some more info in this Fedora bug report: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1560481
It appears that Fedora goes as far as disabling rgb10 in Gallium3D drivers in mesa: https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/mesa/blob/master/f/0001-gallium-Disable-rgb10-configs-by-default.patch
At first I thought this issue was related to this issue in mutter: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/issues/2 but it isn't an issue with mutter (and I actually see the wl_pointer@11.frame messages).

I'm unsure how to proceed however. Perhaps @jadahl can suggest a way forward? Is rgb10 broken under mesa for AMD's drivers or should gnome-shell handle the 10bit colors from mesa somehow? How come this does work under X.org then, don't wayland and x.org use the same video drivers?

events.target_title: Windows randomly become blurry when using HiDPI display and 200% scaling

note.body:
When moving gtk apps (with super + Up/Down, no dragging) between a loDPI display at 100% scale (1080p laptop monitor) and a HiDPI external 4k 27" display set to 200% Scale under GNOME Shell 3.32.2, the terminal is rendered blurry (this happens on both the external and the internal display, but the effect is more pronounced on the 200% display). Dragging the window after I moved it, fixes the blurriness. Additionally I noticed that for gnome-termianl one of three times (one time=moving gnome-terminal from internal to external and back to internal monitor again) the terminal is sharp on the laptop and on the external monitor. Note I am not using fractional scaling.

```
$ gsettings get org.gnome.mutter experimental-features
@as []
$ echo $XDG_SESSION_TYPE
wayland
$ gnome-shell --version
GNOME Shell 3.32.2
```

According to my interpretation of `nautilus --gdk-debug=resize` (Highlight resizing widgets), the window isn't blurry when there is an automatic resize (i.e. I don't manually drag the window after moving it via Super+Up/Dn, but the window is resized anyways) after moving monitors (i.e. the window blinks red with gdk-debug=resize). I can't verify this for gnome-terminal as WAYLAND_DEBUG and --gdk-debug have no effect after a short startup period of the terminal.

Opening Evolution and clicking on the already deleted message:

[logfile.txt](/uploads/e70729cc83ad48e060ade310be43a29a/logfile.txt)

events.target_title: [IMAPx] Option to enable full folder update on metered networks

note.body:
Refresh command: [logfile2.txt](/uploads/ee6f5d6d35e584062dbbe027e2e30fdb/logfile2.txt)

Log of the complete procedure: Start Evolution, click refresh, select the already deleted message, click refresh again: [logfileref.txt](/uploads/cf04a9485a4e51ea157600ae4cbf424b/logfileref.txt)

Quick resync is disabled. Enabling it makes no difference.
After sending some test message back and forth, I'd like to add that the described behavior does not always happen, but approximately 2 out of 3 times.

Meanwhile I upgraded to Evolution 3.32 from the Disco Dingo repo, same there. Downgraded to 3.30.1-1build1 again. The server is running dovecot 2.2.22 on Ubuntu 16.04 but it also happens with dovecot 2.2.27 on Debian 9.

I discovered another thing that might be related. I can reproduce this one more reliably (tried 5 or 6 times and it always occurred):
- Receive 2 new messages while Evolution is running. Both show as unread.
- Close Evolution without reading one of those messages.
- Log in to webmail and mark both messages as read.
- Start Evolution again: The newer message is marked read, but the older one still shows as unread.
Corresponding logfile: [logfile2msgs.txt](/uploads/d422863109e65d3dd0c18379f10bf6a4/logfile2msgs.txt)

The message remains unread until it is either opened in Evolution or deleted using webmail. In that case, it is now gone in Evolution as it should be.

events.target_title: Switch to dark theme variant when Night Light is on

note.body:
>  Web pages simply can't ask the host platform to tell them when to actually use the dark colours.

They can, actually. That's exactly what the [prefer-color-scheme](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@media/prefers-color-scheme) media query is for.

Since macOS Catalina got released last week, I started using its automatic switch-to-dark-mode at night. I don't like dark themes in general, but using it only at night made me feel better about it - because I usually have a pretty poor lightning next to the laptop when I use it at night. I for one really enjoy what Apple did on that, and if major websites started using `prefers-color-scheme`, I would be really happy with a global switch at the GNOME-level.

Synchronized Lyrics

note.body:
It'd be ideal to support offline synchronised lyrics too, though the main problem with that is there are a handful of different formats/specs for them. Off the top of my head there's:
*  ID3's synchronised lyrics (embedded in the file, should work for any format that supports ID3)
*  OggKate (extra stream for Ogg files, not dissimilar to how you'd embed subtitles as a separate stream)
*  Plain subtitles (either embedded or as a separate file, usually using SRT or WebVTT)

Also fyi @aeroplain you can just go to Solus' software center and search for GTK to see what version is available. Currently it's 3.22.30 listed :)

Ver. 2.10.6

events.target_title: Layer masks do not seem to support full 0-255 grayscale range

note.body:
Just made some tests and apparently the Mask uses the linear precision mode regardless of image settings.

How I came this conclusion:
1.  added 4 images: 2x linear precision & 2x perceptual precision
2.  use gradient tool: 2x linear blend-color-space & 2x perceptual blend-color-space
  *  I mean "blend color space" the option for the gradient tool
  *  create/paint: 1x linear precision + linear blend-color-space & 1x linear p + perceptual bcs & 1x .. you get the idea
3.  add mask for each image (Grayscale ofc)
4.  compare all results

result:
*  the 2 images made with linear blend-color-space don't have noticeable differences in image and mask
*  the image with linear precision & perceptual blend-color-space has equal layer and mask but both have low quality
*  the image with perceptual precision & perceptual blend-color-space is the one reported.

events.target_title: GtkFileChooser in save mode does not focus file name entry when saving; instead, it searches

note.body:
I agree that this behaviour is very annoying.
 It also works with any other gnome app, for example **evince**. 
You can reproduce this by:
 1.  open any document, 
 2.  try to save it and open the save as dialog -> type something (you see the name of the file to be changes)
3. select an folder, try typing again -> instead of changing the name of the file it searches for the typed text.
As there is already a search icon in the save-as dialog this behaviour is not needed (or desired in my opinion).
Software versions: evince and gnome shell 3.32.0, archlinux.

3.24.x settings.ini ignored on Wayland
3.24.x settings.ini ignored on Wayland

note.body:
GTK Applications work just fine without dconf on wayland but with default settings only which according to GTK documentation should be overridable using settings.ini.

Removal of dconf is a valid goal, as it is another daemon that needs to be maintained and secured. Additionally, a UI toolkit such as GTK shouldn't require an extra daemon to function properly. For example, QT apps do not require any extra daemons. And the settings portal is just another daemon that needs to be installed.

Regarding action for the bug, documentation in https://developer.gnome.org/gtk3/stable/GtkSettings.html is not working on Wayland. So either the documentation needs to be updated to state that settings.ini is not valid on Wayland or the settings portal changes that cause the bug need to be reverted as it was working before commit of https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/commit/41562ab2c6a2e85f3c1c9027c93882d4e8d7690b

events.target_title: 3.24.x settings.ini ignored on Wayland
3.24.x settings.ini ignored on Wayland

note.body:
>>The documentation is correct. GTK uses settings.ini for default values.

No, since after removing dconf, gsettings-desktop-schemas and recompiling schemas Wayland starts to use default values from the gdk/...wayland...c file ignoring most of the settings in the settings.ini. Also, it's not clear whether the default values in the settings.ini should precede the default values in the XML files or vice versa.

Anyway I found a workaround that avoids this bug. Below are the steps for anyone looking for a solution for this issue in the future.

- Uninstall dconf and gsettings-desktop-schemas with pacman -Rdd
- Create folder at YOURDIRPATH
- Copy the relevant XML files to YOURDIRPATH/glib-2.0/schemas and edit the default values there. 
- Compile schemas with glib-compile-schemas YOURDIRPATH/glib-2.0/schemas
- Add to your app launcher, or .bash_profile or /etc/profile.d/ export XDG_DATA_DIRS=YOURDIRPATH:/usr/share/
- The values should now be overriden

>>What change in behavior did you see due from this commit?

Breaks commit in 790201

note.body:
This issue  is reproduce-able on other gnome apps as well.
I'm coming from Solus 4.0 which runs Budgie Desktop, but the DE relies heavily on gnome tools and gtk still. Settings app is gnome-settings even.

With that said, Me and a friend tested this issue after discovering it by chance on gnome-clocks gnome-weather and gnome-calendar (all 3.28.0) -- all of which would crash (and crash the panel if they're invoked through an applet) on searching for (not even setting) certain cities.

Tested cities were Giza, Egypt (crashes on the z of Giza) and Viana do Castelo, Portugal.

My guess is that the issue in some central database that those apps refer to when searching for cities or something.
if the cities were set before, just opening an app like calendar crashes it right away. But if they weren't, searching for them produces that crash.

I have no knowledge of how to debug this and reproduce logs as I'm not very familiar with how gtk apps do that, but issue reproduction is consistent on my system. Just tell me what logs you want and I will provide.

events.target_title: Unredirected fullscreen clients get forced vsync

note.body:
Well this is embarrassing, `LIBGL_DRI3_DISABLE=1` did help both CSGO and glmark2 ran with unlimited framerates in full screen. 

It appears ```xorg.conf``` was not present on my system, however  after running `Xorg :0 -confgiure` i noticed that the autodetected driver in the "Device" section was actually "modesetting".

After installing appropriate Xorg driver (xf86-video-amdgpu) `Xorg :0 -confgiure` autodetects "amdgpu" driver and the issue appears to be no longer present. 

I've tested CSGO and CNQ3 with xf86-video-amdgpu and both of them now work at same frame rates in both GNOME and XFCE.

Thanks again, and sorry for the wild goose chase.

P.S. `glmark2 --fullscreen` now reports FPS in the range of thousands on the first test, and locks the system on the second benchmark ([build] use-vbo=true).

Again this happens only in GNOME so i suspect the shell crashes, i'll open a new issue once i know more.

Evince resizes window every time it's opened

note.body:
Line 7738 of  shell/ev-window.c  from the current GitHub master says:

	gtk_window_set_default_size (GTK_WINDOW (ev_window), 600, 600);

That looks like the cause of Avenger's problem.  It seems it was not fixed in 3.x.  People have been complaining about this for a decade [[https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=626410](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=626410)].  It is time it was fixed.  At least allowing a command-line argument would allow users to write a wrapper for Evince.

Hard coding the initial window size stopped being acceptable in about 1989.

events.target_title: Initial window is hard coded to 600x600
Initial window is hard coded to 600x600

note.body:
I apologise for the tone of my initial bug report...

I should have said that I'm happy to write a patch if I'm given guidance about what would be acceptable.  My initial thought was to save the most recent window size in the same location as the per-file sizes, and set the default size to that, though I haven't found where that information is saved.  Alternatively, I'd implement a  --geom  argument, like the old  "-geom XxY+x_base+y_base" option.

I assume that there is a reason this was not done a decade ago, and I'd like to understand that before I start coding.

Also, I realised that the reason that there is no  configure is that you use autotools.  I had tried them, but that complains that there is no AM_INIT_AUTOMAKE in configure.ac, among other things.

events.target_title: Initial window is hard coded to 600x600

note.body:
After having apologised for the tone of my initial bug report, I now apologise for its content too...

It seems that you have indeed fixed the bug, and the line I highlighted has nothing to do with setting the initial window size.

Sorry for having wasted you time, and for any offence I have caused.

events.target_title: Initial window is hard coded to 600x600
Initial window is hard coded to 600x600

note.body:
Yes, it was an issue.

Until I rebuilt this week, every time I opened a file (on my notebook with similar resolution to yours), I would have to enlarge it before trying to read it.  Having a window that is half of the screen width may be OK for reading huge fonts, or for young eyes, but I'm middle aged, and need the file to be about 3/4 of my screen width to be able to read a page full of 10pt text comfortably.  That isn't a huge thing, but there is no reason to get the user to perform the same fiddly task for each new file.  Evince is one of the few programs that did this, for no apparent reason.

I can't comment on the fix in 3.x, because it needs libraries newer than those on the latest Ubuntu LTS.  However, my own ~5 line kludge works.  (Atril 1.20.1 -- I'm not sure what version of evince that corresponds to.)

Since people will be using 2.x on LTS for some time to come, it would be great if the fix were back-ported.

Once again, sorry to have been so rude in the initial bug report.  It makes me reluctant to re-open this, even though I do hope that back-port happens.

events.target_title: Metadata issues
JPEG files saved in GIMP 2.10 make Windows 10's File Explorer show a "The size is unexpected" error

note.body:
I've generated a before-and-after EXIF text file using an online Exifextracter tool, to show the differences that arise with the use of GIMP 2.10. As can be seen readily, 2.10.8 introduced some significant changes, especially in "Tag" fields. It's worth noting another difference that's not visible in a text file: 2.10.6 also removed the thumbnail image from the JPEG file, whereas 2.10.8 seems not to do so. My work-around is to revert to 2.8.22, foregoing all the more recent GIMP developments. 

[exifoutput.txt](/uploads/fcefa79dea8108e6e91c0979a5712e6b/exifoutput.txt)

events.target_title: JPEG files saved in GIMP 2.10 make Windows 10's File Explorer show a "The size is unexpected" error

note.body: @pmseligman - Well, I wouldn't have questioned 35,000! My travel cameras have GPS and can extract point-of-interest data from internal "databases" to label my photos (not sure Mongolia has many POIs!). Inconveniently, they save the POI information in a section of metadata (MakerNotes) where they aren't visible with everyday file-viewers. So I use exiftool to extract the POI from its hiding place and put it elsewhere - in one of those "Tag" fields, that GIMP 2.10 appears to dislike. And once I've used GIMP 2.10 on an image, I can no longer use exiftool to make changes. Awkward. So, back to 2.8.22 for now.
